newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian employer, trade union job talks break down.
newsitem.headline: Belgian employer, trade union job talks break down.

text.p: Belgium's employers federation has blamed the FGTB/ABVV socialist trade union for the failure of talks on wages and jobs for 1997-1998 between Belgian unions and employers.

"The FGTB introduced elements which were inacceptable, giving totally different interpretations to those of the other partners and those of the government...," Tony Vandeputte, head of the FEB/VBO employers federation, told Belgian radio in an interview broadcast Wednesday.The talks broke down late on Tuesday.
"In that situation all the partners decided it wasn't possible to have valid negotiations."

The radio said the liberal and Christain unions also blamed the FGTB for the failure of the talks, with all sides angry that the socialist union had published a statement ahead of the talks laying out its own demands.
Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene had given the unions and employers until the end of November to reach an agreement, otherwise the government would impose a deal on them.
Union and employer representatives met with Dehaene on Monday one week after a 24-hour strike by the socialist unions brought negotiations to a standstill.

A government-imposed two-year wage freeze ends on December 31. Unions and employers can agree on nation-wide wage rises in the private sector for the next two years as long as wages do not rise more than those of Belgium's three main trading partners -- Germany, France and the Netherlands.
